Award.AwardTitle: Large-Scale Multiple Testing for High-Dimensional Covariance Structures with Applications to Genomics and Neuroimaging
Award.AbstractNarration:
Analysis of high-dimensional data has emerged as one of the most important and active areas of research in statistics. In particular, hypothesis testing for high-dimensional covariance structures is an interesting and challenging problem with a wide range of applications in areas such as genomics, medical imaging, and the social sciences. The methodology developed in this project will be used to study important problems in genomics and neuroimaging, including identification of interactions between gene pathways and detection of spatial voxels that are activated due to certain experimental stimuli. The proposed methods will be applied to a breast cancer gene expression study and data from fMRI experiments.

In this project, the investigator aims to develop methodology and theory for large-scale multiple testing on high-dimensional covariance structures. The lack of suitable test statistics, as well as the complex entry-wise dependence structures, impose significant methodological and technical challenges not seen in the conventional multiple testing problem. The proposed research is anticipated to make significant contributions to large-scale and high-dimensional inference for covariance structures and its applications to genomics and neuroimaging. Web pages will be created to enable quick access to software implementation of the new methods, as well as technical reports and relevant references.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PI resigned from the university in February 2017, and the grant was only used during the year of 2016. During this period, the PI had three papers accepted, and attended several international conferences for research collaborations.

During this period, this project made contributions and innovations to the large-scale and high-dimensional inference for the covariance structures. The PI developed several new methodologies for large-scale multiple testing on high-dimensional covariance structures with theoretical guarantees.

The methodologies developed in this project were used to study important problems in genomics and neuroimaging, including identification of interactions between gene pathways and detection of spatial voxels that are activated due to certain experimental stimuli, which may play important roles in breast cancer survival and brain disorder cure.

To be specific, the project developed a multiple testing procedure with pre-specified false discovery rate and false discovery proportion control to infer the interactions between gene pathways under the Gaussian graphical model framework. It developed innovative methods to identify the activated voxels in fMRI data and further recover their locations by testing covariance matrices with Kronecker product structures. Furthermore, it applied the newly developed procedures to a range of scientific applications including to breast cancer gene expression study for identifying interactions between pathways and to analyze an ADHD dataset for understanding the different spatial activation patterns among different subtypes of ADHD children and normal children.
